It is difficult to say definitively which option, zero-knowledge proofs or homomorphic encryption, would be better for collecting an accurate crowd-sourced measurement of the signal strength at a given location while defending against bad actors attempting to provide false data. Both options have their own strengths and weaknesses, and the best choice will depend on the specific needs and goals of your crowd-sourcing tool. Here are a few points to consider when deciding between the two options:

1. Zero-knowledge proofs: Zero-knowledge proofs allow a user to prove that they possess certain information (e.g. the strength of their wireless signal) without revealing the actual information itself. This can be useful for protecting user privacy and preventing reverse triangulation, as the actual signal strength is not revealed. However, zero-knowledge proofs can be complex to implement and may not be as widely supported as other cryptographic techniques.
2. Homomorphic encryption: Homomorphic encryption allows data to be encrypted in a way that allows it to be processed and analyzed while it is still encrypted. This can be useful for protecting user privacy and preventing reverse triangulation, as the actual signal strength is not revealed. However, homomorphic encryption can be computationally intensive and may not be practical for large amounts of data.

Ultimately, the best option for your crowd-sourcing tool will depend on the specific requirements and constraints of your use case. It may be helpful to evaluate both options and consider factors such as complexity, performance, and support when making a decision.
